thread.title: Sanders, Clinton duel for Iowans’ support
thread.title_full: Sanders, Clinton duel for Iowans’ support

author:
Ken Thomas and Catherine Lucey 
Associated Press
title: Sanders, Clinton duel for Iowans’ support
text:
Sanders, Clinton duel for Iowans’ support 
Democratic candidates for president speak at key fundraising dinner 
Trailing in polls, Martin O’Malley hopes for breakout performance 
Bill Clinton, Katy Perry headline earlier Iowa rally Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton speaks during the Iowa Democratic Party's Jefferson-Jackson Dinner on Saturday in Des Moines, Iowa. Charlie Neibergall Associated Press Singer Katy Perry reacts as Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton is introduced to speak at the Iowa Democratic Party's Jefferson-Jackson Dinner on Saturday in Des Moines, Iowa. Perry also performed at an earlier rally for Clinton. Charlie Neibergall Associated Press Kira Barker, of Des Moines, Iowa, reacts as Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., speaks during the Iowa Democratic Party's Jefferson-Jackson fundraising dinner on Saturday in Des Moines, Iowa. Charlie Neibergall Associated Press Democratic presidential candidate and former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley speaks during the Iowa Democratic Party's Jefferson-Jackson fundraising dinner on Saturday in Des Moines, Iowa. Charlie Neibergall Associated Press Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., speaks during the Iowa Democratic Party's Jefferson-Jackson Dinner on Saturday in Des Moines, Iowa. Charlie Neibergall Associated Press 1 of 5 
By Ken Thomas and Catherine Lucey 
Associated Press DES MOINES, Iowa 
Hillary Rodham Clinton and Bernie Sanders dueled for support among thousands of Iowa Democrats on Saturday, seeking an edge at a high-profile fundraising dinner that could set the tone for the leadoff presidential caucuses in February. 
Sanders, the independent Vermont senator, used his speech to draw sharp contrasts with Clinton on a number of issues, implicitly criticizing her delayed opposition to the Trans-Pacific Partnership and Keystone XL pipeline as well as her vote in favor of the Iraq war. 
Without naming Clinton, he pointedly criticized the passage of the Defense of Marriage Act during Bill Clinton’s administration, saying, “some are trying to rewrite history by saying they voted for one anti-gay law to stop something worse. That’s not the case.” Hillary Clinton said in an interview with MSNBC on Friday that the law was signed as a “defensive action.” 
“I promise you tonight as your president I will govern based on principle not poll numbers,” Sanders said, eliciting roars from his supporters. “I pledge to you that every day I will fight for the public interest not the corporate interests.” He vowed “not to abandon any segment of American society whether you’re gay or black or Latino or poor or working class – just because it is politically expedient at a given time.” 
I promise you tonight as your president I will govern based on principle not poll numbers. 
Bernie Sanders 
Clinton went after Republicans, warning that they would seek to slash taxes for the wealthy and repeal President Barack Obama’s health care law. 
“I’m running as a proud Democrat,” the former secretary of state said to a large cheering section that waved blue neon sticks. “We need to defend the progress we’ve made under President Obama and build on it until the recovery is secure.” 
Clinton and Sanders sit atop a Democratic presidential field that has effectively pared down to a two-person race for the nomination after Vice President Joe Biden announced this week he would not seek the White House. 
We need to defend the progress we’ve made under President Obama and build on it until the recovery is secure. 
Hillary Rodham Clinton 
Clinton made a direct appeal to Biden’s supporters, saying that by Obama’s side, “every step of the way, has been Vice President Joe Biden. He has fought passionately for middle class families and middle class values.” 
Former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley, who trails both by a wide margin, reached for a breakout performance at the dinner, presenting himself as a fresh face in the party who got things done in his home state. 
“We cannot move beyond today’s gridlocked politics by returning to the divisions of our past,” O'Malley said. “I’m not about that.” 
We cannot move beyond today’s gridlocked politics by returning to the divisions of our past. 
Martin O’Malley 
One hundred days remain before Iowa’s leadoff presidential caucuses, and the state Democratic party’s annual Jefferson-Jackson dinner drew a raucous crowd of more than 6,000 activists in what traditionally serves as a kickoff to the Iowa caucuses. 
It capped a daylong pageant of political activities: Former President Bill Clinton headlined his first rally of the campaign, introducing pop singer Katy Perry at a free concert for Clinton’s faithful. Sanders led cheering supporters across a Des Moines bridge in a march that included chants of “Hey, hey, ho, ho, the oligarchy has to go!” 
Clinton’s campaign has been on an upswing this month. She received a boost from Vice President Joe Biden’s decision not to run, then put together a grinding, competent appearance before a Republican-led congressional committee probing the deadly 2012 attacks on diplomatic outposts in Benghazi, Libya. 
Two lesser-known rivals, Jim Webb and Lincoln Chafee, abandoned the race following Clinton’s strong performance on Oct. 13 in the first primary debate. 
The dinner, called the “J-J,” was an important showcase for Sanders, a Vermont independent who has drawn large crowds with his calls for a “political revolution” to address the gap between the wealthy and the poor.
